oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Buildings; Office buildings; Patriotic societies
United Daughters of the Confederacy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Line drawing of the Baxter Building in Nashville.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: United Daughters of the Confederacy, Nashville Chapter No. 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The National Association of the Daughters of the Confederacy was organized in Nashville, Tenn., on September 10, 1894, by founders Mrs. Caroline Meriwether Goodlett of Nashville and Mrs. Anna Davenport Raines of Georgia. At its second meeting in Atlanta, Ga., in 1895, the organization changed its name to the United Daughters of the Confederacy, by which name it was incorporated under the laws of the District of Columbia on July 18, 1919.
